Comparison of data sources: The expert's investigation revealed that the claim of the CDC readjusting the COVID-19 death toll was not true. They found that the claim was based on comparing two separate data sources that report different measurements.
Provisional Death Counts for Coronavirus: COVID-19) page: The expert referred to the link included in the social media post, which directed them to the CDC's Provisional Death Counts for Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) page. This page provides provisional death totals and other related data based on specific criteria.
Continuous data revision: The expert noted that the provisional data displayed on the CDC's page are continually revised and may be incomplete. The data is lagged by an average of 1-2 weeks, and it can take several weeks for death records to be submitted, processed, coded, and tabulated. Therefore, the data shown on the page may not include all deaths that occurred during a given time period.
Discrepancy with other sources: The expert highlighted that the provisional death counts provided by the CDC's page may differ from other published sources due to the lag in data processing and tabulation. This discrepancy emphasizes the importance of considering multiple sources when analyzing COVID-19 death tolls.
